page.title: 02GORSEHILL WATER TOWER
page.content: This was built between 1902 and 1905. It is 30 metres high, octagonal in shape, with a large platform on top. You get to the top by a spiral staircase with 130 steps. The tower is made of Runcorn stone. The Wallasey News, February 4th. 1905, tells you all about this. It is in Earlston Road Library. The water comes from Lake Vyrnwy in Wales, and water from local wells is also used. There is a storge capacity of six million gallons. A middle aged man told us that on the very top of the tower are the main homing beacons for planes coming from America and even Concorde uses them. There is a small amount of wildlife in the ground around the tower. Foxes live in the gorse and some sparrow hawks and an owl live in the arches.
